r2p.title: Responsibility to Protect (R2P)
r2p.description: The Responsibility to Protect is a principle that states that the international community has a responsibility to protect populations from genocide, war crimes, ethnic cleansing, and crimes against humanity when their own governments are unable or unwilling to do so. R2P was adopted by the UN General Assembly in 2005 and represents a commitment to prevent mass atrocities.
sources: UN General Assembly Resolution 60/1 (2005 World Summit Outcome)
UN Secretary-General's reports on R2P implementation

sdgs.title: Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs)
sdgs.description: The Sustainable Development Goals are a collection of 17 interlinked global goals designed to be a 'blueprint to achieve a better and more sustainable future for all'. The SDGs were set up in 2015 by the United Nations General Assembly and are intended to be achieved by 2030.
sources: UN Department of Economic and Social Affairs

unsc.title: United Nations Security Council (UNSC)
unsc.description: The United Nations Security Council is one of the six principal organs of the UN, charged with ensuring international peace and security, accepting new members to the UN, and approving any changes to the UN Charter. It has 15 members, including 5 permanent members with veto power.
sources: UN Documentation on Security Council procedures

unga.title: United Nations General Assembly (UNGA)
unga.description: The United Nations General Assembly is one of the six principal organs of the UN, serving as the main deliberative, policymaking, and representative organ of the UN. All 193 member states have equal representation in the General Assembly.
sources: UN Documentation on General Assembly procedures

peacekeeping.title: UN Peacekeeping
peacekeeping.description: UN Peacekeeping is a unique and dynamic instrument developed by the Organization as a way to help countries torn by conflict create the conditions for lasting peace. Peacekeeping operations are deployed with the consent of the main parties to the conflict and are guided by three basic principles: consent of the parties, impartiality, and non-use of force except in self-defence and defence of the mandate.
sources: UN Charter Chapter VI and VII

humanitarian.title: Humanitarian Assistance
humanitarian.description: Humanitarian assistance is aid and action designed to save lives, alleviate suffering and maintain human dignity during and in the aftermath of man-made crises and natural disasters, as well as to prevent and strengthen preparedness for the occurrence of such situations.
sources: UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA)
UN General Assembly resolutions on humanitarian assistance

climate.title: Climate Action
climate.description: Climate action refers to efforts to combat climate change and its impacts. The UN plays a central role in international climate negotiations and supports countries in their efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and adapt to climate change impacts.
sources: UN Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC)

refugees.title: Refugee Protection
refugees.description: Refugee protection refers to the international legal framework and practical measures to protect people who have been forced to flee their countries due to persecution, war, or violence. The UN Refugee Agency (UNHCR) leads international action to protect refugees and resolve refugee problems worldwide.
sources: UN General Assembly resolutions on refugees
